post_info.post_title: Is Barack Setting himself up for failure??

Jo Bennett

I think it's a reasonable concern. Everyone is (rightly, given that he couldn't be much worse) expecting him to be better than Bush. From that point, people veer off into their own wish-fulfillment about what precise ways he will be better. My suspicion is that we're just going to get another Clinton, just without the adultery.  Heck yes they do. I think they should be optimistic, but not to the point where they'd lie to themselves about some of his past dubious doings or even ignore them. Steeeeve

Over the past few days all we have heard from the Obama supporters is "he will bring hope and change". This is ridiculous as he will bring much of the same and leave us with some loose change left in our pockets. I support this by pointing out two examples; that his cabinet is full of people who are already DC folks (ie former Clinton or former Bush [1]) and he is already proposing a $800 billion bailout just like Bush's previous 2 that didn't work. We have only had President Obama for less that 24hrs though.
 
 This however was not the question. Obama is actually setting himself up for success and he is smart enough to pull it off (debatable if he can). I define success as people perceiving you are a good president and not that you are actually a good president. 
 
 Obama is setting himself up for success by doing things that will make people happy as opposed to what will be best for them. If you want an analogy think of a fat kid who wants a candy bar. If you give him a candy bar he will like you but you certainly aren't helping him. Some things he is doing is trying to make the economy seem better in the short term (self admitting on his part). So in 4 years he can claim the economy is awesome when it really isn't and we just charged in on the Visa until a future date. This could backfire since this is a different kind of problem but it did work for Bush (another similarity). 
 
 Obama is setting himself in other ways but I won't get specific. He pretty much wants to be a people pleaser and you can set yourself to be one. The bad thing about this is you might end up like Jimmy Carter.

How can one determine its membership?

 
 Socialist International - Progressive Politics For A Fairer World
 
 
Ricardo Lagos, former President of the Republic of Chile and a Special Envoy of the United Nations Secretary-General on Climate Change, and Göran Persson, former Prime Minister of Sweden, have been appointed Co-Chairs of the Commission, and other members are: Hilary Benn, Secretary of State for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, United Kingdom; Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency under President Bill Clinton; Elio di Rupo, leader of the Socialist Party of Belgium; Mohamed El Yazghi, leader of the Socialist Union of Popular Forces, USFP, and Minister of the Government of Morocco; Sigmar Gabriel, Federal Minister for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety, Germany; Aleksandr Kwasniewski, former President of the Republic of Poland; Sergei Mironov, President of the Federal Council of Russia; Cristina Narbona, Minister of the Environment of Spain; Beatriz Paredes, President of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) of Mexico; Anand Sharma, Minister of State for External Affairs of India; Marina Silva, Minister of the Environment of the Federative Republic of Brazil; Martin Torrijos, President of the Republic of Panama and leader of the Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD); and Nkosazana Dlamini Zuma, Minister of Foreign Affairs, Republic of South Africa. 

 
 I thought it best to c/p this membership list, because her name could be scrubbed off of it at any time. Check it quickly, because as is reported by the Washington Times and others "the group's web site was recently scrubbed to remove Browner's picture and biography,..."

I think it's worth reiterating just how non-radical the Socialist International is. Look at the name immediately preceding Browner's on the list - Hilary Benn, arch Blairite and about as moderate as they come. Now, if it had been his Dad, Tony Benn, then you might have had something to be concerned about. I fail to see how an organisation with affiliations from the UK, Israeli and Australian Labo(u)r parties can be in any way considered radical.
marc9000

I think it's worth reiterating just how non-radical the Socialist International is. Look at the name immediately preceding Browner's on the list - Hilary Benn, arch Blairite and about as moderate as they come. Now, if it had been his Dad, Tony Benn, then you might have had something to be concerned about. I fail to see how an organisation with affiliations from the UK, Israeli and Australian Labo(u)r parties can be in any way considered radical.

 
 I think the best way to determine their radicalism is to look at their Declaration of Principles page rather than individual names or small affiliations from significant countries. 
 
 The opening paragraph of their principles says this;
 
 
The idea of Socialism has caught the imagination of people across the world, promoted successful political movements, decisively improved the lives of working men and women, and contributed to shaping the 20th century. 

 
 And, much further down;
 
 
A critical and fundamental challenge of worldwide dimensions is the crisis of the environment. ln both the North and the South, the ecological balance is jeopardised. 

 
 These two things, and most everything in between them on that page, represent radical one-sided U.S. (Democrat) political beliefs. 
 
 One of the things stated in between them said this;
 
 
Peace is equally a necessity within nations. Violent ways of handling conflicts destroy opportunities for development and human rights. Education for peace and disarmament must be intensified. 

 
 The U.S. Constitution authorizes the Congress to "define and punish Piracies and Felonies committed on the high Seas........to declare war.........to raise and support armies.......to provide and maintain a Navy....."
 
 The bottom line is, membership in a global political organization cannot be reconciled with the spirit of the U.S. Constitution. There's simply no room in it for worldwide decision making in U.S. affairs.
Jo Bennett

Saying that war happens too much and is harmful is a statement of fact, as is saying there are too many weapons in the world. So is that fact that socialism, through education, health and welfare systems, has improved the lives of ordinary people immeasurably. Likewise saying the environment is under threat is pretty much a given. Even if one were to accept that these are opinions, the first it common to anyone even remotely left of centre, and many on the right, and certainly to most Christian denominations. The second is simply a reflection of the history of the 20th century, where socialism took us from the "5 giants" (Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness) to situations where, in parts of world, everyone had enough to eat, healthcare, education, sanitation and work. The last is, again accepted by government across the political spectrum, even Margaret Thatcher, who is hardly a radical socialist.
simone

Marc9000, thanks for the link.
 
 Very revealing.
 
 Here's more to the story:
 
 
SI COMMISSION for a Sustainable World Society: First meeting to be held in London
 The Socialist International (SI), the worldwide organisation of social democratic, labour and socialist political parties, will hold the first meeting of its Commission for a Sustainable World Society at 10 Downing Street on Monday 19 November, hosted by Prime Minister Gordon Brown, Leader of the British Labour Party.....
 
 The Commission brings together leading personalities, among them serving and former heads of state and government ministers from different continents, to set out recommendations to tackle these fundamental issues.
 
 ... and Göran Persson, former Prime Minister of Sweden, have been appointed Co-Chairs of the Commission, and other members are: ... Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency under President Bill Clinton...

 Socialist International - Progressive Politics For A Fairer World
 
 Using your rationale as a start, I guess we can also speculate that Gordon Brown is a member as well, since the meeting was held at his digs.
 
 No where is it indicated that Carol Browner is a dues-paying member of SSI.
 
 Clever insinuations, Marc.
marc9000

Saying that war happens too much and is harmful is a statement of fact, as is saying there are too many weapons in the world. So is that fact that socialism, through education, health and welfare systems, has improved the lives of ordinary people immeasurably. Likewise saying the environment is under threat is pretty much a given. Even if one were to accept that these are opinions, the first it common to anyone even remotely left of centre, and many on the right, and certainly to most Christian denominations. 

 
 They are opinions. The first is true only because there is evil in the world, not because governments are not socialistic enough. War happening too much and being harmful is not a new thing, it was that way when the U.S. was founded. A belief that evil will lessen or disappear if the public places its trust in a socialist government is not a belief that the U.S. founders had. In some cases, a mistrust of government by the population could actually prevent a war. 
 
 
The second is simply a reflection of the history of the 20th century, where socialism took us from the "5 giants" (Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness) to situations where, in parts of world, everyone had enough to eat, healthcare, education, sanitation and work. 

 
 What parts? What did the socialism replace that originally resulted in the previous "want, disease, ignorance, squalor and idleness"? Did those things arise from previous freedom, or previous tyranny? Socialism is better than some things (dictatorships/communism, etc) but not better than what we have in the U.S. 
 
 If, as a non-U.S. resident, you get a little tired of hearing Americans claim that the U.S. is "the greatest country in the world", I honestly don't blame you for that. But it's a fact that the U.S. has accomplished a lot for itself and the rest of the world, and it accomplished it with liberty, not socialism. What it has accomplished may have helped make socialism succeed somewhere else, as it replaced some form of tyranny. 
 
 
The last is, again accepted by government across the political spectrum, even Margaret Thatcher, who is hardly a radical socialist.

 
 The belief that the environment is "under threat" is a broad generalization. Many who believe it's threatened in some way don't believe basic political changes need to happen in order to fix it. 
 
 If Browner (and Obama) believe socialism is the best way for the U.S. to go, it would be nice if they would come right out and say it, and make a case for it, rather than trying to sneak it through by doing things like scrubbing some things about Browners past association with a socialist group, that apparently no other politician in the U.S. belongs to.
marc9000

Marc9000, thanks for the link. 

 
 You're welcome, but it wasn't hard to find. 
 
 
Using your rationale as a start, I guess we can also speculate that Gordon Brown is a member as well, since the meeting was held at his digs. 

 
 And your point is? emoticon_confused He wasn't in the members list like Carol Browner is. What does that have to do with it anyway?
 
 
No where is it indicated that Carol Browner is a dues-paying member of SSI. 

 
 You didn't believe she belonged to the SSI at all, and now that I show that she did, you imply that her membership means nothing if I don't get busy and show that she pays dues? If I did THAT, how much further would you move the goalposts? Are you going to be anywhere near Tampa tomorrow - I'm afraid you might disrupt the superbowl. emoticon_frazzled
 
 
Clever insinuations, Marc.

 
 Nothing clever, just an honest look at the real Carol Browner. Why are socialists in U.S. politics so secretive about who they really are?
Jo Bennett

They are opinions. The first is true only because there is evil in the world, not because governments are not socialistic enough. War happening too much and being harmful is not a new thing, it was that way when the U.S. was founded. A belief that evil will lessen or disappear if the public places its trust in a socialist government is not a belief that the U.S. founders had. In some cases, a mistrust of government by the population could actually prevent a war. 
 
 
 
 What parts? What did the socialism replace that originally resulted in the previous "want, disease, ignorance, squalor and idleness"? Did those things arise from previous freedom, or previous tyranny? Socialism is better than some things (dictatorships/communism, etc) but not better than what we have in the U.S. 
 
 If, as a non-U.S. resident, you get a little tired of hearing Americans claim that the U.S. is "the greatest country in the world", I honestly don't blame you for that. But it's a fact that the U.S. has accomplished a lot for itself and the rest of the world, and it accomplished it with liberty, not socialism. What it has accomplished may have helped make socialism succeed somewhere else, as it replaced some form of tyranny. 
 
 
 
 The belief that the environment is "under threat" is a broad generalization. Many who believe it's threatened in some way don't believe basic political changes need to happen in order to fix it. 
 
 If Browner (and Obama) believe socialism is the best way for the U.S. to go, it would be nice if they would come right out and say it, and make a case for it, rather than trying to sneak it through by doing things like scrubbing some things about Browners past association with a socialist group, that apparently no other politician in the U.S. belongs to.

 
 You are committing the fallacy of begging the question. I agree that peace is not an aim solely of socialists, that was entirely my point, you were the one claiming the policy was a sign of radical socialism. My reference to the 5 giants was from the Beveridge report which heralded the creation of the NHS and the welfare state in the UK in the 1940s. The 5 giants were a result of free market capitalism, the first attempts to curb this were implemented by Churchill in the early 1900s. Whether you consider free market capitalism to be freedom or tyranny is rather a matter of opinion. Neither I, nor the Socialist International, are referring to eastern bloc dictatorships whe nwe talk about socialism.
Symbiote

Neither I, nor the Socialist International, are referring to eastern bloc dictatorships whe nwe talk about socialism.

 
 Undoubtedly, neither you, nor the Socialist International, will be talking about South American dictatorships when you talk about socialism once they collapse either.
Jo Bennett

Undoubtedly, neither you, nor the Socialist International, will be talking about South American dictatorships when you talk about socialism once they collapse either.

 
 The only south american dictatorships I'm aware of have been right wing (Pinochet, Galtieri etc.). The bolivarian socialist governments in south america are all democratic. In any case, they are far more radical than the socialist international.
snakespit

Steeeve, your expert reasoning on why Geithner, Daschle and Clinton are stinky.

 
 
Hast thou, then, any solid evidence of their stinkiness?

 
 Wow, Geithner and now Daschle. Tax evasion stinks to me. And as far as Clinton, she gives off a bad smell that is all her own.
simone

SnakeSpit, is your misogyny leaping out of your chest?
 
 Um, perchance, you find the scent of women offensive?
Steeeeve

Wow, Geithner and now Daschle. Tax evasion stinks to me. And as far as Clinton, she gives off a bad smell that is all her own.

 
 It is almost funny. We get Bush who puts a bunch of XXXXXX in cabinet positions (few exceptions) and all the democrats are mad and the republicans say it is no big deal. We then get Obama who puts a bunch of XXXXXX in cabinet positions (few exceptions) and all the republicans are mad and the democrats says it is no big deal. I mean check out todays news: http://bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=ahZUCjwltDRk&refer=home Apparently Obama wants to tap the expert opinions of those running Citi Bank. We all know Citi bank has done such a great job of running their own business, why not get their ideas on the economy. Maybe we can take Citi's policy of moving the bad stuff off the books to make the company look better and apply that to the US.
 
 The American public is left with a bunch of lunacy. 
 
 I actually think Clinton has turned out to be the best choice...so far.
snakespit

SnakeSpit, is your misogyny leaping out of your chest?
 
 Um, perchance, you find the scent of women offensive?

 
 Not at all, I love Al Pacino movies!!! Grow up simone. 
 
 Does the fact that I think Obama was the wrong choice for president make me a racist? 
 
 Does the fact that I thought McCain would have been a horrible president make me an ageist?
 
 I would urge you to take caution in your accusations. In this case the only leaping that took place was your leaping to an assinine conclusion. How very mature of you. emoticon_rolleyes
Symbiote

The only south american dictatorships I'm aware of have been right wing (Pinochet, Galtieri etc.).

 
 I have cuba in mind for one, is it a socialist utopia, or has it progressed to the status of "never was socialist", I have trouble keeping track.
Jo Bennett

I have cuba in mind for one, is it a socialist utopia, or has it progressed to the status of "never was socialist", I have trouble keeping track.

 
 I'd have said that wasn't actually in South America, given that its latitude places it on a level with Mexico, and it's actually in the Carribean. As far as categorising it, Deformed Workers' State would seem pretty close. There are some pluses to the Cuban regime in comparison with, say, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, and other comparable states, but it's not truly socialist because it is undemocratic. As Trotsky said "Socialism needs democracy like the human body needs oxygen".
Matthew

Personally, I think it's great that barely two weeks into his administration, Obama has publicly taken responsibility for more mistakes than Bush did for his first 7 years and 51 weeks. I think it's an indication that the tone is indeed changing -- and also that the new president might actually learn from his mistakes rather than ignore and perpetuate them.
Steeeeve

Personally, I think it's great that barely two weeks into his administration, Obama has publicly taken responsibility for more mistakes than Bush did for his first 7 years and 51 weeks. I think it's an indication that the tone is indeed changing -- and also that the new president might actually learn from his mistakes rather than ignore and perpetuate them.

 
 Actually it indicates to me that we might get into a position where Pelosi and Reid are walking all over Obama. We don't need a push over.
Matthew

Actually it indicates to me that we might get into a position where Pelosi and Reid are walking all over Obama. We don't need a push over.

 
 And we don't have one. Admitting mistakes is not a sign of weakness. Quite the opposite, in fact.
Steeeeve

And we don't have one. Admitting mistakes is not a sign of weakness. Quite the opposite, in fact.

 
 Looking beyond the admission of a mistake is key. Looking at some of the things coming out makes me worried about Pelosi trying to take over leadership from Obama....just look at the stimulus package. 
 
 I hope I'm wrong and we will just wait and see how it plays out.
Matthew

Looking beyond the admission of a mistake is key. Looking at some of the things coming out makes me worried about Pelosi trying to take over leadership from Obama....just look at the stimulus package. 
 
 I hope I'm wrong and we will just wait and see how it plays out.

 
 Fair enough. A bit early to get too pessimistic, but fair enough.
 
 On the other hand, we might also want to remember that the stimulus package is, ultimately, a piece of legislation. The founders actually conceived a much weaker executive in principle than those we've gotten in practice ever since FDR. So up to a point, I'm not even sure it would be entirely bad if Congress reasserted a bit more of its constitutional authority. The President is not a Prime Minister.
Steeeeve

Fair enough. A bit early to get too pessimistic, but fair enough.
 
 On the other hand, we might also want to remember that the stimulus package is, ultimately, a piece of legislation. The founders actually conceived a much weaker executive in principle than those we've gotten in practice ever since FDR. So up to a point, I'm not even sure it would be entirely bad if Congress reasserted a bit more of its constitutional authority. The President is not a Prime Minister.

 
 True, but if they wanted to do their constitutional authority they wouldn't even have a stimulus package and would probably only need to be in session 3 months out of the year. 
 
 So much for that!

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Is Barack Setting himself up for failure??
